description: From Old English þȳrlian (“to pierce”), derived from þȳrel (“hole”) (archaic English thirl).

entries.meaning: A trembling or quivering, especially one caused by emotion.
A cause of sudden excitement; a kick.
(medicine) A slight quivering of the heart that accompanies a cardiac murmur.
A breathing place or hole; a nostril, as of a bird.

verbs.description: thrill (third-person singular simple present thrills, present participle thrilling, simple past and past participle thrilled)

entries.meaning: (ergative) To suddenly excite someone, or to give someone great pleasure; to (figuratively) electrify; to experience such a sensation.
examples: vivid and picturesque turns of expression […]  which thrill the reader with a sudden delight

entries.meaning: (ergative) To (cause something to) tremble or quiver.
(obsolete) To perforate by a pointed instrument; to bore; to transfix; to drill.
(obsolete) To hurl; to throw; to cast.
examples: I'd thrill my jauelin at the Grecian moysture

verbs.description: thrill (third-person singular simple present thrills, present participle thrilling, simple past and past participle thrilled)

entries.meaning: (machining) To drill and thread in one operation, using a tool bit that cuts the hole and the threads in one series of computer-controlled movements.
